words.title: git init
words.meaning: Initialize a Git repository in the current directory.

words.title: git init
words.meaning: Initialize a Git repository in the current directory.

words.title: git clone
words.meaning: Clone a remote repository to your local machine.

words.title: git clone
words.meaning: Clone a remote repository to your local machine. The clone commands allows you to have a copy of your remote repo in your local machine

words.title: repository
words.meaning:
A repository in Git is a collection of files and the complete history of changes to those files. A repository is usually called repo. A repo can be:
# A remote repo or
# A local repo
A remote repo is the repo in your github account while local repo is the repo in your local system

words.title: repository
words.meaning:
A repository in Git is a collection of files and the complete history of changes to those files. A repository is usually called repo. A repo can be:
# A remote repo or

A remote repo is the repo in your github account while local repo is the repo in your local system

words.title: git
words.meaning: Git is a distributed version control system that helps manage software development projects.
words.usage: git is used in front of all git commands!

words.title: git pull
words.meaning:
git pull - fetch and merge any commits from the tracking remote branch.
It is used to synchronize the local repo with the remote repo to ensure that the local repo is up-to-date by downloading and merging the changes from the remote repo into the local branch.
words.usage_more:
Where:
+ [remote-repo] -  the remote repo you want to pull changes from.
+ [branch-name] - local branch you want to pull changes to.
+ If the remote repo and branch name are not specified, git pull will default to the current repo's default remote and branch.

words.title: git pull
words.meaning:
git pull - fetch and merge any commits from the tracking remote branch.
It is used to synchronize the local repo with the remote repo to ensure that the local repo is up-to-date by downloading and merging the changes from the remote repo into the local branch.
words.usage_more:
Where:
+ [remote-repo] -  the remote repo you want to pull changes from.
+ [branch-name] - local branch you want to pull changes to.
+ If the remote repo and branch name are not specified, git pull will default to the current repo's default remote and branch.

words.title: git push
words.meaning: Push changes from the local repository to a remote repository.
words.usage_more: Where <remote> is the name of the remote repository and <branch> is the name of the branch that you want to push to the remote repository.

words.title: git push
words.meaning: Push changes from the local repository to a remote repository.
words.usage_more: Where <remote> is the name of the remote repository and <branch> is the name of the branch that you want to push to the remote repository.

words.title: git commit
words.meaning: Push changes from the local repository to a remote repository.
words.usage_more: Where -m option is used to specify the commit message, which should be a brief description of the changes made in the commit.

words.title: git commit
words.meaning: Push changes from the local repository to a remote repository.
words.usage_more: Where -m option is used to specify the commit message, which should be a brief description of the changes made in the commit.

words.title: git status
words.meaning: Show the status of files in the working tree and the index.

words.title: git status
words.meaning: Show the status of files in the working tree and the index.

words.title: git add
words.meaning: Add a file to the Git index (staging area).
words.usage_more: git add . can be used to stage all files at once

words.title: git add
words.meaning: Add a file to the Git index (staging area).
words.usage_more: git add . can be used to stage all files at once

words.title: git checkout
words.meaning: git checkout is used to switch between branches or restore files in your working directory to a specific version.
words.usage:
# git checkout <branch>
# git checkout master
# git checkout <commit_hash> -- <file_path>
words.usage_more:
# git checkout <branch> - Switches to the specified <branch>.
# git checkout master - Switches to the master branch.
# git checkout <commit_hash> -- <file_path> - It updates the specified file in your working directory to match the version stored in the specified commit.
Where:
+ <commit_hash> - the identifier of the commit that contains the version of the file you want to restore
+ <file_path> - the path to the file you want to restore.

words.title: git checkout
words.meaning: Switches to a different branch.
words.usage:
# git checkout <branch>
# git checkout master
# git checkout <commit_hash> -- <file_path>
words.usage_more:
# git checkout <branch> - Switches to the specified <branch>.
# git checkout master - Switches to the master branch.
# git checkout <commit_hash> -- <file_path> - It updates the specified file in your working directory to match the version stored in the specified commit.
Where:
+ <commit_hash> - the identifier of the commit that contains the version of the file you want to restore
+ <file_path> - the path to the file you want to restore.

words.title: What kind of setup?
words.meaning: If you are looking for git setup search 'git setup'. If you are looking for emacs setup search for 'emacs setup'

words.title: What kind of setup?
words.meaning: If you are looking for git setup search 'git setup'. If you are looking for emacs setup search for 'emacs setup'

words.title: git branch
words.meaning:
# git branch - List all branches in the repository
# git branch [branch-name] - Create a new branch with the specified name
# git checkout [branch-name] - Switch to the specified branch
# git checkout -b [branch-name] - Create a new branch and switch to it in one command
# git merge [branch-name] - Merge the specified branch into the current branch
# git branch -d [branch-name] - Delete the specified branch
# git branch -m [new-branch-name] - Rename the current branch to a new name
# git branch -r - List all the remote branches in a git repo. This is help because it allows you to see the branches other contributors have created or pushed into the remote repo
# git branch --no-merged - Show a list of branches that haven't been merged into the current branch
# git branch -a - List all branches in the repository, including remote branches

# git branch -d [branch-name] - Delete the specified branch
# git branch -m [new-branch-name] - Rename the current branch to a new name
# git branch --no-merged - Show a list of branches that haven't been merged into the current branch
